I was a scientist in the nuclear industry in the 80s and 90s, its going to be a decade before I retire. Ive worked on reactors, reprocessing and warhead production. In the UK. Large reactors can use natural unenriched uranium and are easier to defuel, for Pu239 production. Now. The UK, US and France have too much weapons grade plutonium if anything, so large, difficult to decommission reactors are unnecessary. Theyre massive capital projects SMRs require enriched uranium, but theyre just built in a factory, moved to site, then theyre defuelled and buried when were done with them. Theyre very similar to the submarine reactors that Rolls Royce and Westinghouse Brookfield corp have been making for 60 years. There are also a bunch of startups with high hopes but no engineering experience. My bet is on Rolls Royce. Its a car company that diversified into jet engines and reactors unlike Tesla, which is a car company trying to diversify into novelties and toys. Im also invested in USbased Brookfield because its a great company like an infrastructurefocussed Berkshire Hathaway. Both have been doing very well recently for their shareholders. Small enriched uranium SMRs cant be used to make atom bombs, so they can be made on a production line and sold anywhere without nuclear proliferation concerns. But the 530 enriched fuel has to be purchased from the US, UK, France, China or Russia the nuclear gulf states. Uranium isnt the critical bottleneck you all think it is. The value is added by gas centrifuging UF6. Only governments can do that.

The DD is indeed bending reality. In addition to Vogtle 34, there was another project that survived the postFukushima wipeout of US new nuclear builds. That was V C Summer 23, another pair of AP1000s. Westinghouse was so far behind schedule and over budget in building these four plants that it went bankrupt. Thats why a private equity firm like Brookfield owns them in the first place before it sold half to Comeco. The V C Summer utility decided not to continue, but the Vogtle utility did, at great cost. Its because of this experience and the fact that wind and especially solar are far cheaper these days that no one is looking to build more AP1000s, or any other large nuclear reactors, in the US. Europe has had similar experiences in France, Finland, and the UK. Among nonauthoritarian countries in the last couple of decades, only South Korea has managed to build large nuclear reactors on a reasonable budget and schedule. Id be very wary of all the hype around nuclear, be it uranium, SMRs, or large reactors.

I think we can safely classify China as authoritarian. The UAE too. Haiyang and Sanmen are AP1000s, which, fwiw, is a really great design with excellent safety features. But yes, theyre building a bunch of clones on their own because Westinghouse gave them the IP.

Oh, the AP1000 is a great design, as youll see downthread on the other reply to my comment. Definitely the best LWR design currently on the market. But the nuclear industry always claims that theyll learn their lessons and the next build will be smoother and on time and budget. And it never is. Basically every plant built in the 70s and 80s in the US had huge overruns, and many were cancelled after TMI. Even Watts Bar took much longer to complete than expected. Flamanville in France and Olkiluoto in Finland were similar. Frances original build out in the 70s was similarly over. Taiwan ended up cancelling the ABWRs in Longmen, and that was after a dozen or so were built in Japan. Unless youre an authoritarian country, or maybe South Korea, youre very likely to take far more money and time to build every large nuclear reactor. This time wont be different. This is unfortunately why the nuclear industry, which should be a perfect complement to solar and wind, and perfect for AI, is instead a sunset industry.

CORZ is at 9.47 right now. That means each of your 4 strike calls has 5.47 of intrinsic value. Anything above that is the premium of the call. If your call expires inthemoney, your broker should exercise it for you. But beware! You will need enough cash to actually buy the shares! Same goes for when you exercise the call early. If I were you, I would set a limit sell order and slowly adjust it lower until I hit 5.47. At some point a bot should jump at it, considering thats where premium is 0. If you dont get a fill above 5.47, it would be better to exercise early. But exercising always carries an overnight risk. They cant help you sell them. The only thing they can do for you is exercise them. What many brokers will tell you is that they will automatically exercise the contracts by expiration if they are in the money. This is a lie, they wont do this. What they actually do is sell the contracts at market price a couple of hours before they expire. What this actually means is you will lose a lot of money, because market orders for options are absolutely atrocious. Especially when volume is non existent like this. Market orders can and often will be below fair value when volume is this low. Your best bet is to try to sell these yourself. Try to split the bid, consistently lower your price every 15 minutes or so until your order fills. If this doesnt happen at a fair price then just exercise the options and sell the shares.
If the contract expires before you sell the contracts or exercise your right to purchase the shares at strike price, you lose your investment meaning your contract will be worth 00.00.

Yes, thats a possibility with some brokers. In reality, they still do take on a risk doing that, because there are several hours between when settlement occurs and when market resumes trading. For options that expire on Fridays, the settlement actually happens on Saturday many hours after the market has closed and trading doesnt start for more than 24 hours later. The stock can open with a gap up or down when trading resumes. Thats the risk the broker is taking. The risk being that your account gets wiped out and the broker is left carrying the rest of the loss. Brokers with deep pockets can take those risks to offer smoother services to their clients.

Selling the option should theoretically always yield a higher return, since you are receiving a premium on top of the intrinsic value of the shares. Lets use 4 strike, and a 9.47 share price. The equilibrium point where both scenarios yield the same return is when the following equation is equal. Im going to try to explain the jargon and answer this as clearly and thoroughly as I can. The answer to your first question is entirely dependent on which broker you are using and how your account is set up. The worst thing you can do here is nothing. You are right that open interest means that there are 1700ish open orders for that call contract. However, the bid or the highest price anyone is willing to pay looks like its about 20 cents below the ask or the lowest price anyone is willing to sell. If you want to close your position immediately and the bid price is acceptable to you, you can put your order through to sell all of the contracts at whatever the current bid price is and they will sellclose almost immediately at that price. You will not be maximizing your profits, but youll immediately end your position in this trade and make a nice profit. Since you are very new to this, this is the choice I would recommend. You are potentially leaving some additional profit on the table, but if youre happy with the profit so far, this strategy makes the most sense and immediately ends your risk of the underlying stock moving against you and the option price dropping. Your other choice is to exercise the contract and buy the shares. Even for calls that are deep in the money, this is pretty much never a good idea. You will need to have the cash in your account, or if you have a margin account, you will need to borrow the money from your broker and pay interest to buy the shares. You will be massively increasing your investment and your exposure to price movements. If you paid 500 for these contracts, the most you could lose is 500 if they expire worthless. If you buy the shares and the company goes bankrupt, you will have lost the total value of the shares you bought. Your last choice is to do nothing and see what your brokerage does. If youre even considering this, I would recommend closing your account after this trade and putting your money into a managed fund like a 401k or IRA. When you opened a brokerage account you decided to make decisions about your money. These are not managed accounts, we are the managers, we have to make these decisions. I dont know how anyone on here would recommend not putting an order in to your broker to do something. If you dont tell your broker what to do, they would be completely justified in letting your calls expire worthless and you will lose your entire investment. They may have a policy in place that they will try to close them for you at the best price they can get, but I wouldnt rely on that. You should look into something called theta decay when youre done with this, basically the options market understands that huge fluctuations in stock prices are rare. So as a contract nears its expiration date, its value decreases even if the underlying stocks price doesnt change. When youre buying puts and calls, your profit potential is based on the uncertainty of the price of the stock, and as you get closer to the expiration date, the stock price becomes more predictable and the value of the options decreases. You should consider this when deciding when it is best to close your positions. oh, and can you do a cashless exercise? maybe, thats up to you and your broker. Again, that would not be my choice. And can you exercise your options buy the shares and sell them the same day usually yes as long as you have not been flagged as a pattern day trader. I think if you make more than 4 day trades buying and selling an asset within one trading day in a 5 day period and your account has less than 25k in it, then your broker will flag you as a pattern day trader and youll need to wait a day to sell.
No. You will be assigned or they will sell it at market price. Set a limit sell at or near bid or call to exercise early so you can take advantage of further upticks.

Worth reading is the Aug. 20th North Texas Daily article about CORZ's Denton facility power contract amendment to allow for AI hosting from original mining only operations. Per that article, it seems that the municipal power company are only too willing for such amendments as they will make more money because power supply for AI (which never turns off) will be greater for the city. The existence of these power agreements are the competitive advantage for CORZ as they have locked up both producers' and transmitters' existing supply - i.e., there is no more excess power for other AI infrastructure companies in the locale. IMO, CORZ is sitting on a gold mine with these contracts and, keep in mind, with the types of contracts that CORZ has in place with companies like Coreweave, they don't really care about the ultimate increase in power prices because this is a direct pass-through. In essence, CORZ is monetizing their existing power contracts for some serious cash - a great position to be in. Companies (e.g., MARA) that were asset light in their mining approach, has no chance in the AI business competitively because they don't have the power lock-ups that CORZ has. Good luck to us longs.

Because take CLSK for example, she has one of the lowest - if not the lowest cost to mine. Thus, say CLSK mines a coin for $30 - 40k, they instantly receive that coin at nearly 100% profit if they are to sell it, which they dont. They hold, hence when btc doubles (rises 100%) the recently mined coin poses a 200% gain. When bitcoin doubles again (rises to 200%), that recently mined coin poses a 400% gain. Therefore we can conclude that an increase in BTC should entail an even larger increase in CLSKs value and the sharper the increase in BTC the sharper the increase in CLSK. Its an exponentially leveraged play. BTC just increased sharply, thus CLSK, CORZ, and other good miners even sharper. This explains why miners may increase despite bitcoin dropping in general.
